'''Greg Brockman''' (born November 1988) is an [[United States|American]] technology [[business_executive|executive]] and [[software engineer]].<ref name="bizcarson">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/stripes-cto-greg-brockman-is-leaving-the-company-2015-5|title=Stripe's CTO Greg Brockman is leaving the company - Business Insider|author=Biz Carson|date=6 May 2015|work=Business Insider}}</ref>

He is the former founding [[Chief Technology Officer]] (CTO) of American [[payment_processor|payments]] corporation [[Stripe_(company)|Stripe]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/2014/07/the-startup-that-wants-to-change-the-language-of-online-payments/|title=The Internet Needs a Better Way to Handle Money. This Startup Has the Key|date=23 July 2014|work=WIRED}}</ref> and currently serves as the CTO of the [[artificial intelligence]] non-profit [[OpenAI]], which he co-founded with technology entrepreneurs [[Elon Musk]] (of [[Tesla Motors|Tesla]] and [[SpaceX]]) and [[Sam Altman]] (of [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/openai-cto-greg-brockman-on-artificial-intelligence-2015-12|title=OpenAI CTO Greg Brockman on AI - Business Insider|author=Matt Weinberger|date=11 December 2015|work=Business Insider}}</ref><ref name="robertmcmillanandalistairbarr">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2015/12/11/silicon-valley-kingpins-commit-1-billion-to-create-artificial-intelligence-without-profit-motive/|title=Silicon Valley Kingpins Commit $1 Billion to Create Artificial Intelligence Without Profit Motive|author=Robert McMillan and Alistair Barr|work=WSJ}}</ref> The company is supported by over $1 billion in pledges from partners including [[Amazon Web Services]], [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]], and [[Infosys]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breitbart.com/tech/2015/12/13/musk-thiel-hoffman-invest-1-billion-in-artificial-intelligence/|title=Musk, Thiel, Hoffman invest $1 Billion in Artificial Intelligence|work=Breitbart}}</ref>

==Career==

===Stripe===

Brockman left MIT to join [[Stripe (company)|Stripe]] in 2010.{{cn|date=January 2016}} Stripe is an online payments processor used by [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], [[Salesforce.com|Salesforce]], and others.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://stripe.com/gallery|title=Stripe Gallery: Kickstarter, Facebook, Shopify, Lyft, Warby Parker, and thousands of other businesses use Stripe to power payments|publisher=}}</ref> In 2013, he assumed the role of Chief Technology Officer.<ref name="bizcarson"/> 

At Stripe, Brockman introduced an "open by default" email policy to [[Stripe (company)|Stripe]]'s internal communications, which was cited in the [[technology]] and [[business]] press as a novel approach to fostering company culture.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://research.gigaom.com/2013/02/open-email-at-stripe/|title=Gigaom  Open email leads to ’emergent coordination’|author=Stowe Boyd|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3005791/fast-feed/stripe-embraces-open-emails|title=Stripe Embraces Open Emails|date=12 February 2013|work=Fast Company}}</ref><ref name="wired.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/2014/12/startup-everyone-can-read-others-email/|title=At This Startup, Everyone Can Read Each Other's Email|date=19 December 2014|work=WIRED}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lifehacker.com/how-to-feel-more-connected-when-your-whole-team-works-r-1688265162|title=How to Feel More Connected When Your Whole Team Works Remotely|author=Belle Beth Cooper|publisher=Gawker Media|work=Lifehacker}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/To-avoid-embarrassing-hacks-don-t-send-5961265.php|title=To avoid embarrassing hacks, don’t send embarrassing e-mails|author=Thomas Lee|date=17 December 2014|work=SFGate}}</ref> The implementation of email transparency, which consisted of employees' opted-in business-related emails being openly shared across the company, aimed to improve the empowerment of workers within the organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://stripe.com/blog/scaling-email-transparency|title=Scaling email transparency|publisher=}}</ref> [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] described the methodology as "apply[ing] an engineering mindset to communication in an organization: the fewer hops from one node to the next, the more efficient the group."<ref name="wired.com"/> [[Silicon Valley]] tech companies, including [[Khan Academy]] and [[Buffer_(application)|Buffer]], adopted the approach to organizational transparency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bjk5.com/post/71887196490/email-transparency-at-khan-academy|title=Ben Kamens|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://joel.is/how-we-handle-team-emails-at-our-startup-defaulting-to/|title=How we handle team emails at our startup: Defaulting to transparency|work=Joel Gascoigne}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.frontapp.com/spreading-email-transparency-or-why-you-should-share-your-inbox-with-your-team/|title=Spreading email transparency, or why you should share your inbox with your team|publisher=}}</ref>

===OpenAI===

After leaving Stripe in May 2015, Brockman founded the non-profit [[artificial intelligence]] research company [[OpenAI]].<ref name="singularityhub.com">{{cite web|url=http://singularityhub.com/2015/12/20/inside-openai-will-transparency-protect-us-from-artificial-intelligence-run-amok/|title=Inside OpenAI: Will Transparency Protect Us From Artificial Intelligence Run Amok?|work=Singularity HUB}}</ref> He co-founded the company with technology entrepreneurs [[Elon Musk]] and [[Sam Altman]].<ref name="robertmcmillanandalistairbarr"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/technology/silicon-valley-investors-to-bankroll-artificial-intelligence-center/|title=Silicon Valley investors to bankroll artificial-intelligence center|date=13 December 2015|work=The Seattle Times}}</ref> To fund the initiative, over $1 billion was pledged by [[Silicon Valley]] corporations and founders, including [[Peter Thiel]], [[Reid Hoffman]], [[Amazon Web Services]], and [[Infosys]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/12/science/artificial-intelligence-research-center-is-founded-by-silicon-valley-investors.html|title=Artificial-Intelligence Research Center Is Founded by Silicon Valley Investors|date=12 December 2015|work=The New York Times}}</ref> 

In an announcement post, OpenAI described itself as being founded on the premise that digital [[artificial intelligence]] (AI) could be tremendously beneficial to society, but it could also be harmful if built or used incorrectly.To ensure a positive outcome, OpenAI employs leading AI scientists to pursue research with the mandate to, as Brockman describes, “advance digital intelligence in a way that is most likely to benefit humanity as a whole."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/2015/12/elon-musk-snags-top-google-researcher-for-new-ai-non-profit/|title=Elon Musk Snags Top Google Researcher for New AI Non-Profit|date=11 December 2015|work=WIRED}}</ref>

Brockman is responsible for designing the team's operating structure and recruiting researchers from the field,<ref name="singularityhub.com"/> including former [[Google]] scientist and [[neural network]] pioneer Ilya Sutskever as Research Director and Durk Kingma (inventor of the [[autoencoder#Variational_Autoencoder_.28VAE.29|variational autoencoder]]) as a scientist.{{cn|date=January 2016}}
